article.paragraph: TheChinese calendaris alunisolar calendarwhich arranges the year, month and day number upon the astronomical date. It is used for traditional activities in China and overseas Chinese communities. It determines the date for the Chinese traditional holidays, and instructs Chinese people in selecting the lucky day of a wedding or funeral, for opening a venture, or a relocation.

In the Chinese calendar, the days begin and end at midnight. The months begin on the day with thenew moondark (new) moon. The years begin with the dark moon near the midpoint betweenwinter solsticeandspring equinox. Thesolar termsare the important components of the Chinese calendar. There are one or two, and occasionally three, solar terms within a month.

The present Chinese calendar is the product of evolution. Many astronomical and seasonal factors were added by ancient scientists, and people can reckon the date of natural phenomena such as the moon phase and tide upon the Chinese calendar. The Chinese calendar has over 100 versions, and the characteristics of these versions reflect the evolutionary route of the Chinese calendar. Like Chinese characters, these versions of Chinese calendar are adopted throughout the Sinosphere. In Korea, Vietnam, and the Ryukyu Islands, the Chinese calendar was adopted completely. In Japan, the Chinese calendar was used before the Edo period, and the later Japanese calendar used the algorithm of the Chinese calendar.

The official calendar in China is theGregorian calendar, but the traditional Chinese calendar plays an important role there. The official name of the Chinese calendar is theRural Calendar(zh農曆农历Nónglì), but people often refer to the Chinese calendar with other names, such as theFormer Calendar(zh舊曆旧历Jiùlì), theTraditional Calendar(zh老曆老历Lǎolì), or theYin and yangYinCalendar(zh陰曆阴历Yīnlì).
article.heading: Structure
Codes
article.paragraph: Several coding systems are used for some special circumstances in order to avoid ambiguity, such as continuous day or year count.

list.listitem: Theheavenly stemsis a decimal system. The characters of the heavenly stems are:ji, y, bng, dng, w, j, gng, xn, rn, gu(zh甲乙丙丁戊己庚辛壬癸).

Theearthly branchesis a duodecimal system. The characters of the earthly branches are:z, chu, yn, mo, chn, s, w, wi, shn, yu, x, hi(zh子丑寅卯辰巳午未申酉戌亥). The earthly branches are used to mark theshand climate terms usually.

TheSexagenary cyclestem-branchesis a sexagesimal system. Theheavenly stemsandearthly branchesmatch together and formSexagenary cyclestem-branches. The stem-branches are used to mark the continuous day and year.

article.heading: Day, hour, and week
article.paragraph: In the Chinese calendar, the days begin at midnight and end at the next midnight, but people tend to regard the days as beginning at dawn.

Currently, the time in days are scaled with hour-minute-second system.
In ancient China, the time is divided according to either thesh-kandgng-dinsystems. There are 10gngor 12sh, 60dinor 100k, 6000fnin a day. For example:Chinese Time
Currently, the days are grouped into 7-day weeks and the weekdays are marked with the ordinal number except Sunday.
In ancient China, the days were grouped into 60-day weeks with the stem-branches.
article.heading: Month
article.paragraph: In the Chinese calendar, the months begin on the day of the dark moon, and end on the day before the next dark moon. There are 29 or 30 days in a month, but the month length is float. The month with 30 days is called the long month (zh大月), and the month with 29 days is called the short month (zh小月). The days in the months are marked with the ordinal number from 1. However, in the Chinese calendar, the dates are normalized to two characters, such asChy(zh初一),Shw(zh十五),Ninsn(zh廿三).

As a practice, the months are divided into 3xn(zh旬). The first 10 days is theearly xn(zh上旬), the middle 10 days is themid xn(zh中旬), and the last 9 or 10 days is thelate xn(zh下旬). The ten-day week was used in antiquity (reportedly as early as in the Bronze AgeXia Dynasty).cite book海上 《中國人的歲時文化》 岳麓書社 2005 195 7-80665-620-0The law in theHan Dynasty(206 BC AD 220) required officials of the empire to rest every five days, calledmu(), while it was changed into 10 days in theTang Dynasty(AD 618 907), calledhuan(/) orxn(). Months were almost three weeks long (alternating 29 and 30 days to keep in line with thelunation). The weeks were labelledshng xn(),zhng xn(), andxi xn() which mean roughly "early", "mid" and "late" week. Markets in Japan followed the Chinesejun() system; seeJapanese calendar. In Korea, it was called "Sun" (,).
article.heading: Relation between moon phases and dates
article.paragraph: The first day of each month is the day with dark moon.In the 7th or 8th day of each month, the first quarter moon is visible in the afternoon and early evening. In the 15th or 16th day of each month, the full moon is visible all night, and in the 22nd or 23rd day of each month, the last quarter moon is visible late at night and in the morning .
article.heading: Solar year and solar term
article.paragraph: In the Chinese calendar, thetropical yearsolar year(zh岁歲Suì) is the time from awinter solsticeto the next winter solstice. The solar year is divided into 24 solar terms which corresponding to 15 along the ecliptic each. Two solar terms are associated with each climate term. The beginning of the first term in each climate term is labelled "pre-climate" (zh节气節氣Jiéqì), and the beginning of the last term in each couple is labelled "mid-climate" (zh中气中氣Zhōngqì).

table.tablecaption: The ecliptic position of each solar term

article.paragraph:
In a solar year, there are 11 or 12 whole months. The year with 11 whole months is a common year. The year with 12 whole months is a leap year, and the first month without a mid-climate is the intercalary month.
The months in the solar year are numbered with the ordinal number from 0, except the intercalary month. The intercalary month follows the number of the previous month.
article.heading: Relations between solar terms and months
article.paragraph: The Chinese use an astronomical calendar, and the years and months are irregular. But, there are some rhythms for the laws of astronomy.

article.heading: Year
article.paragraph: In the Chinese calendar, the years begin on the 1st day of the 1st month, and the first and last month are named asZhngyu(zh正月) andLyu(zh腊月臘月) specially. The stem-branches are used to count the year, and according to usual practice, each branches corresponds an animal zodiac. people used to call the animal zodiac. After the era system was abolished, the stem-branches is the only formal year numbering method.

There are 12 or 13 months in a year. The years with 12 months are common years, there are 353, 354 or 355 days in the common year. The years with 13 months are leap years, there are 383, 384 or 385 days in the leap year. For example, the year fromChinese Traditional Yearis aChinese Traditional YearsborChinese Traditional Yearpz(Chinese Traditional Yearpzl),Chinese Traditional Yearremark,Chinese Traditional Yearllong.
article.heading: Age recognition in China
article.paragraph: In China, age for official use is based on the Gregorian calendar. For traditional use, age is based on the Chinese calendar. From birthday to the end of the year, it's one year old. After each New Year's Eve, add one year. For example, if one's birthday isLyu29th 2013, he is 2 years old atZhngyu1st 2014. On the other hand, people say months old instead of years old, if someone is too young. It's that the age sequence is "1 month old, 2 months old, ... 10 months old, 2 years old, 3 years old..."

After the actual age (zh實歲实岁) was introduced into China, the Chinese traditional age was referred to as the nominal age (zh虛歲虚岁). Divided the year into two halves by the birthday in the Chinese calendar,The birthday is the day in each year that have the same date as the one on which someone was born. It's easy to confirm the birthday in the Chinese calendar for most people. But, if someone was born on the 30thof a month, his birthday is the last day of that month, and if someone is born in an intercalary month, his birthday is the day with the same date in the common month of the intercalary month.the nominal age is 2 older than the actual age in the first half, and the nominal age is 1 older than the actual age in the second half (zh前半年前虚两岁,后半年虚一岁前半年前虛兩歲,後半年虛一歲).The Gregorian calendar is a solar calendar and the Chinese calendar is a lunisolar calendar, and the birthday in the Chinese calendar is not same as in the Gregorian calendar always. so, there's a bias of +/-1 between the actual age in the Chinese calendar and in the Gregorian calendar. Thus, the nominal age in the Chinese calendar is 0~3 older than the actual age in the Gregorian calendar.
article.heading: Year number system

list.listitem: Era system

article.paragraph: In the ancient system, the years are numbered from 1 when the new emperor ascended the throne or the authority released the reign title. The first reign title isJinyun(zh建元建元, from 140 BC), the last reign title isXuntng(zh宣统宣統, from 1908). The era system was abolished in 1910. The Christian era orRepublic of China (191249)Republican eratook over to express the year in the Chinese calendar.
On the other hand, the Christian era is simulated in the 20th century, such as:
Anno Hungd (zh黄帝紀年), upon the beginning of the reign of theYellow Emperor, 2698+AD=AH
Anno Yo (zh唐尧紀年), upon the beginning of the reign ofEmperor Yao, 2156+AD=AY
Anno Gngh (zh共和紀年), upon the beginning of theGonghe Regency, 841+AD=AG
Anno Confucius(zh孔子紀年), upon the birth year ofConfucius, 551+AD=AC
Anno Unity (zh統一紀年), upon the beginning of the reign ofQin Shi Huang, 221+AD=AU

Generally, no reference date is widely accepted. On January 2, 1912,Sun Yat-sendeclared a change to the official calendar and era. In his declaration, January 1, 1912 is calledShyyu 13th, 4609 AHwhich implied an epoch of 2698 BC. The implication was adopted by manyoverseas Chinesecommunities outsideSoutheast Asiasuch asChinatown, San FranciscoSan Francisco's Chinatown.Aslaksen, p.38.

In the 17th century, theJesuit China missionsJesuitstried to determine what year should be considered the epoch of the Han calendar. In hisSinicae historiae decas prima(first published inMunichin 1658),Martino Martini(16141661) dated the ascension of theYellow Emperorto 2697 BC, but started the Chinese calendar with the reign ofFuxi, which he claimed started in 2952 BC.Philippe Couplet's (16231693)Chronological table of Chinese monarchs(Tabula chronologica monarchiae sinicae; 1686) also gave the same date for the Yellow Emperor. The Jesuits' dates provoked great interest in Europe, where they were used for comparisons with Biblical chronology. Modern Chinese chronology has generally accepted Martini's dates, except that it usually places the reign of the Yellow Emperor in 2698 BC and omits the Yellow Emperor's predecessors Fuxi andShennong, who are considered "too legendary to include".

Starting in 1903, radical publications started using the projected date of birth of theYellow Emperoras the first year of the Han calendar. Different newspapers and magazines proposed different dates.Jiangsu, for example, counted 1905 as year 4396 (use an epoch of 2491 BC), whereas the newspaperMing Pao(zh明報明报) reckoned 1905 as 4603 (use an epoch of 2698 BC).Liu Shipei(langzh-t劉師培; 18841919) created the Yellow Emperor Calendar, now often used to calculate the date, to show the unbroken continuity of the Han race and Han culture from earliest times. Liu's calendar started with the birth of the Yellow Emperor, which he determined to be 2711 BC. There is no evidence that this calendar was used before the 20th century.sfnbCohen20121, 4Liu calculated that the 1900 international expedition sent by theEight-Nation Allianceto suppress theBoxer RebellionenteredBeijingin the 4611th year of the Yellow Emperor.

list.listitem: Calendric epoch

article.paragraph: There is an epoch for each version of the Chinese calendar, which is calledLyun(zh曆元历元). The epoch is the optimal origin of the calendar, and it's aJizr, the first day of a lunar month, and the dark moon and solstice are just at the midnight (zh日得甲子夜半朔旦冬至日得甲子夜半朔旦冬至). And tracing back to a perfect day, such as that day with the magical star sign, there's a supreme epoch (zh上元上元shàngyuán). The continuous year based on the supreme epoch isshngyun jnin(zh上元積年上元积年). More and more factors were added into the supreme epoch, and theshngyun jninbecame a huge number. So, the supreme epoch andshngyun jninwere neglected from theShushcalendar.

list.listitem: Yun-Hu-Yn-Shsystem

article.paragraph: Shao Yong(zh邵雍邵雍10111077), a philosopher, cosmologist, poet, and historian who greatly influenced the development ofNeo-Confucianismin China, introduced a timing system in hisThe Ultimate which Manages the World(zh皇极经世皇極經世Huángjíjīngshì)In his time system, 1yun(zh元元), which contains 12'9600 years, is a lifecycle of the world. Eachyunis divided into 12hu(zh会會). Eachhuis divided into 30yn(zh运運), and eachynis divided into 12sh(zh世世). So, eachshis equivalent to 30 years. Theyun-hu-yn-shcorresponds withnin-yu-r-sh. So theyun-hu-yn-shis called themajor tendor thenumbers of the heaven, and thenin-yu-r-shis called theminor tendor thenumbers of the earth.

Theminor tendof the birth is adapted by people for predicting destiny or fate. The numbers ofnin-yu-r-share encoded with stem-branches and show a form ofBz. Thenin-yu-r-share called theFour Pillars of Destiny. For example, theBzof theQianlong EmperorisXnmo, Dngyu, Gngw, Bngz(langzh辛卯、丁酉、庚午、丙子). Sho'sHungjjngshrecorded the history of the timing system from the first year of the 180thynor 2149thsh(HYSN 0630-0101, 2577 BC) and marked the year with the reign title from theJichnninof the 2156thsh(HYSN 0630-0811, 2357 BC,Tngyo 1,zh唐堯元年唐尧元年). According to this timing system, 2014-1-31 isHYSN/YR 0712-1001/0101.

list.listitem: Theplum rains seasonis the rainy season during the late spring and early summer. Theplum rains seasonstarts on the firstBngrafter the Corn on Ear, and ends on the firstWirafter the Moderate Heat.

Thedog daysSanfu daysare the three sections from the firstGng-dayafter the summer solstice. The first section is 10 days long, and named thefore fu(zh初伏chūfú). The second section is 10 or 20 days long, and named themid fu(zh中伏zhōngfú). The last section is 10 days long from the firstGng-dayafter autumn commences, and named thelast fu(zh末伏mòfú).
TheShujiu cold daysare the nine sections from the winter solstice. Each section is 9 days long. Theshjuare the coldest days, and named with an ordinal number, such asSju(zh四九).
Theforecast of drought(zh分龙分龍) is the key day which forecast if it's a drought year. the day is the firstChnrafter the Summer Solstice.

article.heading: History
Earlier Chinese calendars
article.paragraph: Before the Spring and Autumn period, the Chinese Calendars were solar calendars. According to literature, the first version was the five-phases calendar (zh五行历五行曆). In the five-phases calendar, the year begins at the Vernal Commences, and consists of 10 months and a transition. Each month is 36 days long, and the transitions are 5 or 6 days long. The months are named with the heavenly stems, and a couple of months form a phase. Phases are named withWu Xingfive-phases. The second version is the four-seasons calendar (zh四时八节历四時八節曆). In the four-seasons calendar, the year begins at the Vernal Commences, and consists of 12 months and a year day.
article.heading: Ancient Chinese calendars

list.listitem: Pre-Qin dynastycalendars

article.paragraph: During theWarring States period, the primitive lunisolar calendars are established by the rulingZhou dynastyand its vassal states. Several representative calendars are theYellow Emperor's calendar (zh黃帝曆黄帝历),Zhuanxu's calendar (zh顓頊曆颛顼历),Xia dynastyXia's calendar (zh夏曆夏历),Shang dynastyYin's calendar (zh殷曆殷历),Zhou dynastyZhou's calendar (zh周曆周历), andLu (state)Lu's calendar (zh魯曆鲁历). These six calendars are called as the six ancient calendars (zh古六曆古六历), and are the quarter remainder calendars (zh四分曆四分历sìfēnlì). The months of these calendars begin on the day with the darkmoon, and there are 12 or 13 month within a year. The intercalary month is placed at the end of the year, and called as 13th month. But, the year beginning is different in these calendars. The years in the Xia calendar begin on the day with the darkmoon close to the Vernal Commences. The years in the Yin calendar end on the last day of the month with theWinter Solstice. The years in the Yellow Emperor's calendar, Zhou's calendar, and Lu's calendar begin on the first day of the month with the Winter Solstice. And, the years in the Zhuanxu's calendar begin on the day with the darkmoon close to the Winter Commences.

list.listitem: Calendar of the Qin and earlyHan dynastyHandynasties

article.paragraph: AfterQin Shi Huangunified China under the Qin dynasty, the Qin's calendar (zh秦曆秦历) was released. The Qin's calendar follows the rules of Zhuanxu's calendar, but the months order follows the Xia calendar. The months in the year are from the 10th month to the 9th month, and the intercalary month is called as the second Jiuyue (zh後九月后九月). In the early Han dynasty, the Qin calendar continued to be used.

list.listitem: Taichu calendar and the calendars from the Han toMing dynastyMingdynasties.

article.paragraph: Emperor Wu of HanEmperor Wuof the Han dynasty introduced reforms in the halfway of his administration. His Taichu or Grand Inception Calendar (zh太初曆太初历)introduced 24 solar terms which decides the month names. The solar year was defined as 365385/1539days, and divided into 24 solar terms. Each couples of solar terms are associated into 12 climate terms. The lunar month was defined as 2943/81days and named according to the closest climate term. The mid-climate in the month decides the month name, and a month without mid-climate is an intercalary.

The Taichu calendar established the frame of the Chinese calendar, Ever since then, there are over 100 official calendars in Chinese which are consecutive and follow the structure ofTichcalendar both. There're several innovation in calendar calculation in the history of over 2100 years, such as:

article.heading: Modern Chinese calendars

list.listitem: Shxincalendar

article.paragraph: In the lateMing dynasty,Xu Guangqiand his colleagues worked out the new calendar upon the western astronomical arithmetic. But, the new calendar is not released before the end of the Ming dynasty. In the earlyQing dynasty,Johann Adam Schall von Bellsubmitted the calendar to theShunzhi Emperor. The Qing government released the calendar with a name, theShxincalendar, which means seasonal charter.In theShxincalendar, the solar terms each correspond to 15 along the ecliptic. It makes the Chinese calendar develop into an astronomical calendar. However, the length of the climate term near the perihelion is shorter than 30 days and there may be two mid-climate terms. The rule of the mid-climate terms decides the months, which is used for thousands years, lose its validity. TheShxincalendar changed the rule to "decides the month in sequence, except the intercalary month".

list.listitem: Current Chinese calendar

article.paragraph: Currently, the Chinese calendar follows the rules of theShxincalendar, except that: changed the baseline to the Chinese Standard Time, and adopt the real astronomical data of observatories against the theoretical calculation.

list.listitem: Optimize the Chinese calendar

article.paragraph: To optimize the Chinese calendar, astronomers and astrophiles released many proposals. A typical proposal was released by Gao Pingzi (zh高平子; 1888-1970), a Chinese astronomer who was one of the founders ofPurple Mountain Observatory. In his proposal, the month numbers are calculated before the dark moons and the solar terms were rounded to day. Upon his proposal, the month numbers are the same for the Chinese calendar upon different time zones.
article.heading: Other practices
article.paragraph: Among the ethnic groups inhabiting the mountain and plateau of southwestern China, and those living in the grasslands of northern China, the civil calendars shows a diversity of practice upon the characteristic phenology and culture, but they are based on the algorithm of the Chinese calendar of different periods, especially those of the Tang dynasty and pre-Qin dynasty period. For example, the Thai, Tibetan and Mongolian calendar is based on the algorithm of the Tang dynasty, while the Miao and Yi calendar is based on the algorithm of the pre-Qin dynasty period.
